(BDR 54-148) FISCAL NOTE: Effect on Local Government: Increases or Newly Provides for Term of Imprisonment in County or City Jail or Detention Facility. Effect on the State: Yes. ~ EXPLANATION - Matter in bolded italics is new; matter between brackets [omitted material ] is material to be omitted. AN ACT relating to physician assistants; prescribing the settings in which a physician assistant is authorized to practice; revising the membership of the Board of Medical Examiners; authorizing physician assistants to perform medical services without the supervision of a physician; authorizing a physician assistant to perform certain medical services under certain circumstances; eliminatin g provisions governing the testing or examination of applicants for licensure as a physician assistant; prescribing certain authority and duties of a physician assistant and an advanced practice registered nurse; authorizing certain unlicensed persons to u se the title "inactive physician assistant"; removing the requirement that a rural clinic be supervised by a physician; and providing other matters properly relating thereto. Legislative Counsel's Digest: Existing law: (1) provides for the licensure and r egulation of physician 1 assistants by the Board of Medical Examiners and the State Board of Osteopathic 2 Medicine; and (2) requires a physician assistant to work under the supervision of a 3 physician or osteopathic physician. (NRS 630.271, 630.275, 633.432 -633.469) 4 Sections 5, 10-12, 24 and 26-28 of this bill remove the requirement that a 5 physician assistant be supervised by a physician or osteopathic physician. Sections 6 9, 21, 29, 30, 32, 35, 36, 81-84, 90, 98, 168, 169 and 204 of this bill remove 7 references to supervision of a physician assistant by a physician or osteopathic 8 - 2 - - *AB364_R1* physician. Sections 4 and 23 of this bill require a physician assistant who has 9 practiced for less than 6,000 hours as a physician assistant or who has change d the 10 field of medicine within which the physician assistant practices to enter into a 11 collaborative agreement with a physician. Sections 4 and 23 also prescribe the 12 settings in which a physician assistant is authorized to practice. Sections 10 and 26 13 of this bill: (1) require a physician assistant to obtain the informed consent of a 14 patient before providing any medical service; (2) prescribe medical services that a 15 physician assistant is authorized to perform; and (3) require a physician assistant to 16 only perform such services within his or her scope of practice and which he or she 17 has the necessary education, training and experience to competently perform. 18 Sections 12 and 28 of this bill remove a requirement that the Board of Medical 19 Examiners and the State Board of Osteopathic Medicine adopt regulations 20 governing the testing or examination of applicants for licensure as a physician 21 assistant and the services which a physician assistant may perform. Section 30 22 makes a technical revision concerning the r enewal of a license as an osteopathic 23 physician assistant. 1-3, and 170-201 of this bill make various changes so that physician 25 assistants have similar authority and duties to other providers of health care who 26 provide medical services independently and are otherwise treated in the same 27 manner as other such providers of health ca re. Sections 54, 56, 70, 126, 142 and 28 178 of this bill also add advanced practice registered nurses to certain provisions to 29 ensure that physician assistants and advanced practice registered nurses have 30 similar authority. 31 Existing law provides that the Bo ard of Medical Examiners consists of: (1) six 32 licensed physicians; (2) one representative of the interests of persons or agencies 33 that regularly provide health care to persons who are indigent, uninsured or unable 34 to afford health care; and (3) two residen ts of this State who are not affiliated with 35 the healing arts. (NRS 631.050) Existing law also authorizes the Board to select 36 physicians and members of the public to serve as advisory members of the Board. 37 (NRS 630.075) Sections 7 and 202 of this bill revise the membership of the Board 38 to eliminate one member who is a licensed physician and instead require the 39 appointment of one member who is a physician assistant. Section 8 of this bill 40 authorizes the Board to select physician assistants to serve as advisory members of 41 the Board. 42 Existing law prohibits a person who is not licensed as a physician assistant 43 from holding himself or herself out as a physician assistant. (NRS 630.400, 44 633.7 41) Sections 17 and 32 of this bill authorize an unlicensed person who meets 45 the requirements for licensure as a physician assistant to refer to himself or herself 46 as an "inactive physician assistant." 47 Existing law requires the State Board of Pharmacy to adopt regulations 48 governing the: (1) administration, possession, d ispensing, storage, security, 49 recordkeeping and transportation of controlled substances by a physician assistant; 50 and (2) administration, possession, prescription, dispensing, storage, security, 51 recordkeeping and transportation of dangerous drugs, poisons and devices by a 52 physician assistant. (NRS 639.1373) Section 36 removes a requirement that the 53 Board consider the experience and training of the physician assistant when adopting 54 those regulations. 55 Existing law establishes a rural clinic as a medical faci lity in a rural area where 56 medical services are provided by a physician assistant or advanced practice 57 registered nurse under the supervision of a physician. (NRS 449.0175) Section 128 58 of this bill removes the requirement that a rural clinic be supervised by a physician. 59 - 3 - - *AB364_R1* THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEVADA, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEMBLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS: Section 1.
